Poor oral health is preventable. To reduce inequalities, we have produced guidance documents that include toolkits for water fluoridation and supervised-tooth brushing. 

You can read more in our inequalities in oral health report: https://t.co/gpPX8zJW5s

Despite good progress over the last few decades to improve oral health, inequalities remain a significant public health problem in England. 

We have found that there are barriers to care which include costs and lack of access to services: https://t.co/gpPX8zJW5s

Today we have published data and evidence on inequalities in oral health in England. It shows that poor oral health disproportionately affects vulnerable and socially disadvantaged groups. 

You can read more here: https://t.co/gpPX8zJW5s

The JCVI, which advises government on vaccine use and prioritisation, regularly reviews data and evidence on #vaccine efficacy and effectiveness.
Evidence shows that the #vaccine is working in older people and among healthcare workers and this will help prevent the virus spreading among clinically vulnerable groups.
We know that people whose immune systems are compromised may not respond as well to the #vaccine, which is why it‚Äôs vital that these groups continue to shield in line with the guidance.

It‚Äôs important to remember that the study looks at people‚Äôs immune responses to the #Pfizer #COVID19 #vaccine but did not measure actual protection. It involves very small numbers of people and has not yet been peer reviewed.

We know some people may be concerned at reading about the findings of this study, which looks at the immune response to the first dose of the #Pfizer #COVID19 #vaccine in #cancer patients: https://t.co/3X2wUVYU96

If you‚Äôve had a cough for three weeks or more and it isn‚Äôt COVID-19, it could be a sign of cancer. 

It‚Äôs probably nothing serious, but if it is cancer, finding it early makes it more treatable. 

Your NHS is here to see you, safely. https://t.co/Ptp8v4f0Ok

Get tested and self-isolate if you have any symptoms of #COVID19.

The most common symptoms are :
‚ñ™Ô∏è a new continuous cough
‚ñ™Ô∏è a high temperature
‚ñ™Ô∏è a loss of, or change in, your normal sense of taste or smell

More info on getting a test: https://t.co/qnc1pxgkCp https://t.co/XWgJXmbE3y

Let plenty of fresh air into your home. 

If someone in your household is self-isolating, open a window in their room and keep the door closed to reduce the spread of contaminated air to other parts of the house.

Read more: https://t.co/XZFq0x8Ehl https://t.co/dTVWeiyUEG

Wear a face covering on public transport, in shops, and in indoor places where social distancing might be difficult.

Remember that some people may be exempt from wearing a face covering for medical reasons.

More info: https://t.co/XZFq0x8Ehl https://t.co/5orv3laYtr

Clean surfaces often, especially surfaces that people touch frequently such as door handles.

Cleaning surfaces reduces the amount of potential contamination, reducing the risk of viruses spreading.

More info on reducing the spread of #COVID19: https://t.co/XZFq0x8Ehl https://t.co/G1W4FC5PrN

Wash your hands with soap and water or use hand sanitiser regularly throughout the day, especially after coughing or sneezing, or before handling food.

If you leave home, make sure you wash your hands as soon as you return.

More info: https://t.co/XZFq0x8Ehl https://t.co/DJhQK3FLm2

If you need to leave your home, it‚Äôs important to keep a safe distance from others.

Stay at least 2m from other people and reduce your time spent in crowded areas such as shops, where it may be difficult to socially distance.

More info: https://t.co/XZFq0x8Ehl https://t.co/29v1CWw74B

In people aged over 80 who develop #COVID19 infection, those who are vaccinated have around half (56%) the risk of dying than someone with infection who hasn‚Äôt been vaccinated.

Over 80s who develop #COVID19 infection after vaccination are around 40% less likely to be hospitalised than someone with infection who has not been vaccinated.

https://t.co/OyFWBpEMLC https://t.co/Ge4lxbAN8C

In people aged 80 and over, protection from any #COVID19 symptoms is 57% from four weeks after vaccination with the Pfizer-BioNTech #vaccine.

https://t.co/w1gAWCjATz

This new report is another piece of the puzzle which adds detail to our understanding of #COVID19.

The findings will help focus where interventions could improve health outcomes for ethnic minority communities.

Our analysis shows Black African and Black Caribbean ethnic groups had a similar risk of dying once diagnosed with #COVID19 to White ethnic groups. 

High COVID-19 mortality in these groups was largely due to high risk of infection.

New analysis shows lower #COVID19 survival rates in Bangladeshi, Pakistani, Chinese, & Indian ethnic groups remained after adjusting for comorbidities.

It‚Äôs likely timing of tests and treatment & socioeconomic factors contributed to poorer outcomes.

Our new report has looked at the relationship between pre-existing health conditions and the health impact of #COVID19 among different ethnic groups during the first wave of the pandemic. 

Read more here: https://t.co/IE6Pj8ll4o
